class.name: BulletFactory2D
class.brief_description: The heart of the BlastBullets2D plugin. Use this to spawn bullets.
class.description:
You should have a single [b]BulletFactory2D[/b] node inside your scene. The factory does all the work in spawning bullets and configuring other plugin related options (save/load state, object pooling, physics interpolation, debugger etc..). Keep a reference to your [b]BulletFactory2D[/b] node throughout the lifetime of your game and call the functions you need.
Note: To handle collisions register the [signal area_entered] and [signal body_entered] signals. You also have the option of tracking when the bullets' lifetime is over by registering the signal [signal life_time_over], but this is only enabled if the [MultiMeshBulletsData2D] you pass to the spawn functions has the [member MultiMeshBulletsData2D.is_life_time_over_signal_enabled] property set to true. Note: You can attach a script to the node, but never override Godot functions like [code]_ready[/code]. Note: Never use [code]set_process[/code]/[code]set_physics_process[/code], always use [member is_factory_processing_bullets] to determine whether the plugin is paused or not (bullets stop moving). Note: Object pooling is automatic, bullets are [b]never destroyed[/b] by default, but you do have the option of freeing the object pools whenever you want. Note: Never use [code]queue_free[/code] on already spawned bullets or your game will crash. The plugin has its own bullet tracking logic.
The way you use the factory is the following: 1. Add [b]BulletFactory2D[/b] to the scene tree and save this reference in a variable so that you can access it in every script you want (autoload or a static variable). 2. Use the spawn functions to spawn bullets (You will have to set up [MultiMeshBulletsData2D] properly (pick [BlockBulletsData2D] or [DirectionalBulletsData2D]). You might get an instant crash if you are missing mandatory properties, so be aware of that). 3. Optionally use any of the other functions that the [b]BulletFactory2D[/b] provides.

method.name: debug_get_active_attachments_amount
method.description: Get the amount of active [BulletAttachment2D] nodes.

method.name: debug_get_active_bullets_amount
method.description: Get the amount of active bullet multimeshes of a specific type.

method.name: debug_get_attachments_pool_amount
method.description: Get the amount of [BulletAttachment2D] inside the object pool.

method.name: debug_get_attachments_pool_info
method.description: Get the whole information about the attachment object pool. Returns a [Dictionary] containing [b]attachment_id as the KEY[/b] and [b]amount of attachments with that attachment_id as the VALUE[/b].

method.name: debug_get_bullets_pool_amount
method.description: Get the amount of bullet multimeshes of a specific type currently in the object pool.

method.name: debug_get_bullets_pool_info
method.description: Get the whole information about the bullet multimeshes object pool of a specific type. Returns a [Dictionary] containing [b]amount bullets in the multimesh as the KEY[/b] and the [b]amount of multimeshes that contain exactly that amount as the VALUE[/b].

method.name: debug_get_total_attachments_amount
method.description: Get the total amount of [BulletAttachment2D] in the scene tree.

method.name: debug_get_total_bullets_amount
method.description: Get the total amount of bullet multimeshes of a specific type in the scene tree.

method.name: free_active_bullets
method.description: Frees all active bullets that are currently in the scene tree. Additionaly you have the option to return all the [BulletAttachment2D] nodes to the object pool if you set [code]pool_attachments[/code] to true.

method.name: free_attachments_pool
method.description: By default completely frees the [BulletAttachment2D] object pools. You also have the option of freeing only the attachments with a particular [code]attachment_id[/code] if you provide a value that is not a negative number.

method.name: free_bullets_pool
method.description: By default completely frees an object pool of a particular bullet type. You also have the option of freeing only the instances that each have a particular [code]amount_bullets_per_instance[/code] if you provide a value that is bigger than 0. Example: if you want to free all those multimeshes in the object pool that each have 200 bullets each ([code]amount_bullets_per_instance=200[/code]).

method.name: get_is_factory_busy
method.description: Sometimes the [b]BulletFactory2D[/b] might be busy doing some important work. This property provides an easy way to check if that's true.

method.name: get_physics_space
method.description: Get the physics world space in which the bullets interact.

method.name: helper_generate_transforms_grid
method.description: Generates a grid of transforms that are positioned relative to the [code]marker_transform[/code].

method.name: load
method.description: Loads bullets data. Emits the [signal load_finished] signal when finished.

method.name: populate_attachments_pool
method.description: Populates the attachments object pool. Ensure that the [code]bullet_attachment_scene[/code] contains an actual [BulletAttachment2D] scene or your game will crash. Check the [BulletAttachment2D] documentation for more info on how attachments work.

method.name: populate_bullets_pool
method.description: Populates a specific [code]bullet_type[/code] object pool. The [code]amount_instances[/code] is the amount of multimeshes, while the [code]amount_bullets_per_instance[/code] determines how many bullets each multimesh instance has.

method.name: reset
method.description: Resets the factory - free everything (object pools, spawned bullets, spawned attachments - all get deleted from memory). Emits the [signal reset_finished] signal when complete.

method.name: save
method.description: Generates a [SaveDataBulletFactory2D] that contains the state of the bullets. When finished, emits the [signal save_finished] signal with the saved data so you can decide what to do with it (save it on disk as a save file etc..).

method.name: set_physics_space
method.description: Sets the world physics space that the bullets interact in.

method.name: set_use_physics_interpolation_runtime
method.description: Controls whether physics interpolation is enabled or not for all bullets controlled by the [b]BulletFactory2D[/b].

method.name: spawn_block_bullets
method.description: Spawns [BlockBullets2D] - bullets that act as a block that travels in a single direction. These bullets can NOT be controlled individually, but they are more efficient performance wise.

method.name: spawn_controllable_directional_bullets
method.description:
Spawns DirectionalBullets2D that are meant to be controlled and edited. If there is a multimesh available in the object pool then it gets re-used with the new data. Use if you want homing bullets or to edit properties during runtime.
Warning: Since object pooling is enabled by default, if you save these bullets to an array you might accidentally push the exact same multimesh (you end up with 2 references or more to the same exact object)

method.name: spawn_directional_bullets
method.description: Spawns [DirectionalBullets2D] - bullets that have individual directions determined by the rotation of their transforms. To control these bullets individually, use the [method spawn_controllable_directional_bullets] function instead.

members.member: The color for the collision shapes of all [BlockBullets2D].
The color for the collision shapes of all [DirectionalBullets2D].
Whether the debugger of the collision shapes is enabled or not.
Use this if you want to pause processing of bullets - being able to stop bullets in place. Always use this instead of [code]set_process[/code]/[code]set_physics_process[/code].

Determines whether physics interpolation is enabled or not. The setter is for the editor only.
Instead always use [method set_use_physics_interpolation_runtime] if you are doing changes during runtime.

signal.name: area_entered
signal.description: Emitted when a bullet enters a physics area.

signal.name: body_entered
signal.description:
Emited when a bullet enters a physics body.
Note: Static bodies can be detected by the bullets, but only if you set the [MultiMeshBulletsData2D]'s [member MultiMeshBulletsData2D.monitorable] property to [code]true[/code] when spawning bullets - this is at the cost of performance of course, so it's better to stick with [Area2D] or other types of bodies for enemies/buildings etc and leave the [member MultiMeshBulletsData2D.monitorable] property to be false.

signal.name: life_time_over
signal.description: Emitted when a bullet multimesh's lifetime is over, but only if the [MultiMeshBulletsData2D]'s [member MultiMeshBulletsData2D.is_life_time_over_signal_enabled] is set to [code]true[/code].

signal.name: load_finished
signal.description: Emitted when the loading of data has finished.

signal.name: reset_finished
signal.description: Emitted when the reset of the state has finished.

signal.name: save_finished
signal.description: Emitted when the saving of data has finished.
